title: Tol'able David
descriptions:
In the heart of the rural Virginia mountains, "Tol'able David" (1921) unfolds the story of David Kinemon, a young, simple-hearted, and eager man who yearns to prove his worth to his family and community. David, played by Richard Barthelmess, lives with his parents and older brother on a humble farm, yearning for the day he can step into his brother's shoes as the family's provider.

The arrival of the nefarious Hatburn clan—consisting of Iscah, a cunning patriarch, and his three brutish sons—disrupts the peace in their quiet town. The Hatburns are notorious for their criminal ways and wreak havoc wherever they go. David's family has a longstanding feud with the Hatburns, and as tensions rise, David's chance to prove himself finally presents itself.

When his older brother Allen, the local mail carrier, gets injured in a bar fight with the Hatburns, David seizes the opportunity to take over the mail route. Though his parents initially object due to David's perceived inadequacy, the kind-hearted boy convinces them that he is capable.

As David embarks on his new role, he encounters Esther Hatburn—the daughter of the family's sworn enemies—and her younger brother. Esther, a young woman trapped in an abusive family, finds solace in David's kindness. In turn, David finds himself falling for Esther and vows to rescue her from the clutches of her violent clan.

Meanwhile, the Hatburn brothers plot to steal a shipment of money from the local bank. They carry out their plan, leaving David as the prime suspect in the theft. The community turns against David, but Esther, with her unwavering faith in him, helps clear his name.

In a climactic showdown, David confronts Iscah Hatburn, who tries to shoot him. Esther's younger brother intervenes, attempting to protect David, and is tragically killed by his own father's bullet. Overwhelmed by grief and rage, David finally proves his mettle by defeating Iscah in a brutal fistfight.

With the Hatburns vanquished and justice served, the townspeople hail David as a hero. Though heartbroken over the loss of Esther's brother, David finds solace in the love and respect he has earned. "Tol'able David" concludes with the young man's transformation from an underestimated boy to a revered man, proving that even the most unassuming individuals can rise above adversity and become true heroes.
